messages.content: Don't make assumptions about what values to plug into functions. Ask for clarification if a user request is ambiguous.
I can help look up your address or nearby landmarks—but I’ll need your coordinates. Could you please share your latitude and longitude?

No worries. If you can’t grab latitude/longitude, you can instead tell me any of the following:

• The city or town you’re in  
• A nearby landmark or street address  
• Anything else that describes your location  

With that I can help figure out where you are.
I don't know anything about my current place.

If you’re not sure where you are, the easiest way is to let your device tell us. Here are two simple options:

1. Share your device’s location via your browser or app  
   • On many phones/tablets: when prompted by the browser or app, tap “Allow” for location access.  
   • Once you grant permission, let me know and I can read your latitude/longitude directly.

2. Manually grab your GPS coordinates  
   • Open a map app (Google Maps, Apple Maps, etc.).  
   • Tap the blue “You are here” dot.  
   • It will show you a pair of numbers (latitude, longitude). Copy those and paste them here.

Either way, once I have your latitude and longitude, I can look up your address or nearest landmark. Let me know if you need help with either step!
I can't access any location services right now.

I’m still blind to your surroundings until you can share at least a little bit of location data. Here are some “no-GPS” tricks you can try—then pass me whatever you find and I’ll help pinpoint where you are:

1. Check your device’s time-zone setting  
   • iOS: Settings → General → Date & Time → Time Zone  
   • Android: Settings → System → Date & Time → Time Zone  
   The zone name (e.g. “America/Los_Angeles”, “GMT+1”) will at least narrow you to a region.

2. Look up your mobile-carrier or Wi-Fi network name  
   • iOS: Settings → General → About → Network  
   • Android: Settings → About Phone → Status → Network  
   • Or simply note the SSID of the Wi-Fi you’re on (e.g. “Starbucks-Guest,” “CityLibrary-FreeWifi”).  
   Even a chain-store or institution name can get us very close.

3. Use IP-based geolocation via a web lookup  
   – In your browser, search “what is my IP address?” and copy the number you get (e.g. 203.0.113.45).  
   – Then visit a site like ipinfo.io or iplocation.net—they’ll show you a city/region (and often lat/lon).  
   Share the resulting city/coordinates here.

4. Spot visual clues around you  
   – Street signs, business names, bus/train numbers, license-plate codes, local currency…  
   – Even the language on signs or the style of road markings can pin down a country or city.

If you gather any one of those data points—time zone, carrier/network name, public-IP lookup result, or visual clue—just paste it here. With that I can identify exactly where you are.
